newsitem.title: USA: WMX to cut 3,000 jobs, divest $1.5 billion in assets.
newsitem.headline: WMX to cut 3,000 jobs, divest $1.5 billion in assets.

text.p: WMX Technologies Inc., reporting a fourth-quarter loss of more than $460 million, said Tuesday it planned to divest $1.5 billion in assets over the next two years and cut 3,000 jobs, including 1,200 this year.
The announcement disappointed investors, who sent the company's stock plunging $3.375, or 9 percent, to $32.75 on the New York Stock Exchange, where it was one of the most heavily traded issues.
Under fire from dissatisfied shareholders for months, WMX said its restructuring was geared toward meeting several long-standing demands of investors.

A share buyback, sale of non-core assets and certain management changes had been on the agendas of several activist shareholders, including George Soros' hedge-fund group and Lens Inc., an activist shareholder group in Washington.

WMX -- which also announced it was changing its name back to Waste Management Inc. as it refocuses solely on waste management services -- said it was reorganizing its management, buying back shares and cutting capital spending as it tries to get its balance sheet back in order.
"We will add value by concentrating on the basics of the waste management services business," the nation's largest garbage hauling and handling company said in a statement.
The company said it took a $680 million charge in the fourth quarter, when it lost $461.3 million, or 95 cents a share. That compared with a profit of $49.7 million, or 10 cents a share, a year ago.
Revenues edged up to $2.33 billion from $2.25 billion in the period.
For the full year, net income fell 68 percent to $192.1 million, or 39 cents a share, from $603.9 million, or $1.24 a share. Revenues rose to $9.19 billion from $9.05 billion.
The company, based in Oak Brook, Ill., also predicted that its revenues this year would not improve over last year's.
"There's a lot of disappointment here. There's a feeling that some of these changes are too late," said Argus Research industry analyst James Kelleher.

Raymond James analyst William Fisher said, "The quarter appeared to be below expectations and core growth appeared lackluster ... You can do all the restructuring you want, but if your core growth isn't there, well."

WMX said the divestments, to take place in the next 18 to 24 months, were part of a comprehensive change in business strategy that should generate $3 billion in free cash after dividends over the next two years.
It said the reorganization plan also includes cutting its capital budget for 1997 to $900 million from $1.1 billion in 1996.

Under the plan, WMX's Wheelabrator Technologies subsidiary will sell its remaining water services units for $77 million, and its Rust International unit will sell its remaininng engineering and consulting businesses.
WMX also said it would sell about $400 million of non-integrated waste services business in North America and cut its investment in all or parts of its businesses in France, Spain and Austria.

"This seems like WMX is just admitting it made some mistakes ... They went into these markets and got a half a foot in the door and now they're pulling it out. It's acknowledgment of a failed strategy," Kelleher said.

He added that Wall Street was concerned the asset sales may come on the market at a time when other garbage handlers are also divesting businesses. "Conditions are not ideal for getting a fair value," Kelleher said.

The company said it will save a total of about $300 million over the next two to three years through initiatives that include cutting 1,200 jobs in 1997 and a total of 3,000 in a two-to-three year period.
The job cuts will be accomplished through attrition, early retirement and staff cuts, it said.
Counting jobs eliminated with discontinued businesses, WMX said it will have fewer than 58,000 employees this year, down from about 73,000 at the beginning of 1996.
The company also said its board had approved a two-year, 50-million share repurchase programme to return free cash to shareholders.
